[5] Generally speaking, urea appearance rates in the mucosal saline were higher in fed tissues compared with the respective fasted tissues.  [6] Specifically, mucosal urea appearance rates were 1.5-fold higher in fed tissues exposed to control mucosal saline (70.8Â±9.9 nmol N hâˆ’1 cmâˆ’2), rates similar to fed tissues exposed to high ammonia saline (58.5Â±7.2 nmol N hâˆ’1 cmâˆ’2; Fig. 2C).  [7] As seen with fasted tissue, exposure to a high glutamine mucosal saline reduced urea mucosal appearance rates threefold to 23.5Â±7.0 nmol N hâˆ’1 cmâˆ’2, and exposure to a high ammonia and high glutamine mucosal saline recovered urea appearance rates to control saline values (Fig. 2C).  [8] The appearance rate of urea in the mucosal saline was higher in fasted

fish exposed to antibiotics compared with fasted fish and similar to concentrations found in fed fish with each respective mucosal treatment.  [9] Once again, exposure to high glutamine significantly reduced the appearance rate of urea in the mucosal solution; however, values remained above those seen in both fasted and fed fish (38.9Â±4.9 nmol N hâˆ’1 cmâˆ’2; Fig. 2C). [10] Treatment with high ammonia and high glutamine partially recovered the appearance rate of urea in the lumen (49.4Â±4.1 nmol N hâˆ’1 cmâˆ’2), but not back to control saline values as seen without antibiotic treatment (Fig. 2C). [11] The serosal appearance rate of urea was influenced only by condition, and not mucosal saline treatment.
